definition: The Deutsches Afrikakorps (DAK) was the German expeditionary force in North Africa commanded by Erwin Rommel from 1941-1943. It consisted primarily of the 15th and 21st Panzer Divisions.
German word for 'armor' or 'tank.' Panzer divisions were Germany's armored formations, combining tanks, motorized infantry, and artillery for mobile warfare.
Imperial Germany's highest military decoration, informally known as the 'Blue Max.' Rommel received this honor for his actions at the Battle of Caporetto in 1917.
Nickname for Rommel's 7th Panzer Division during the 1940 invasion of France, earned because it advanced so rapidly that even German headquarters lost track of its position.
The vital waterway connecting the Mediterranean to the Red Sea. Britain's control of the canal was essential for communications with India and the Far East.
The British offensive in December 1940 that destroyed the Italian Tenth Army in Egypt and Libya, capturing 130,000 prisoners and prompting Germany to send forces to Africa.
The Allied invasion of French North Africa (Morocco and Algeria) on November 8, 1942. It was the first major American ground operation against Germany.
The British Commonwealth force that defended Egypt and fought in Libya from 1940-1941, later reorganized as the Eighth Army.
The nickname adopted by the Australian and other Allied defenders of Tobruk during the 241-day siege in 1941, embracing a German propaganda insult.
A 50-mile defensive line of fortified 'boxes' and minefields built by the British in early 1942, stretching from Gazala on the coast to Bir Hakeim in the south.
The British offensive in November-December 1941 that relieved the siege of Tobruk and pushed Rommel back to El Agheila.
Egyptian town and railway station 60 miles west of Alexandria. The site of two crucial battles in 1942 that marked the turning point of the North African Campaign.
British special forces unit founded by David Stirling in 1941. Originally designed for behind-the-lines raids on Axis airfields in North Africa.
British reconnaissance and raiding unit specializing in desert operations. The LRDG transported SAS teams to their targets and pioneered desert navigation techniques.
A combined incendiary and explosive device developed by Jock Lewes of the SAS, specifically designed for destroying parked aircraft.
The original designation for the SAS: 'L Detachment, Special Air Service Brigade.' The name was chosen to deceive German intelligence into believing a large airborne force existed.
The German 88mm Flak 36/37 anti-aircraft gun, adapted by Rommel as a devastating anti-tank weapon. Its long range and high velocity made it the most feared weapon in North Africa.
American medium tank that arrived in North Africa in 1942. While not superior to German tanks individually, it was reliable, easy to maintain, and produced in vast numbers.
British 'infantry tank' with heavy armor but slow speed. Effective against Italian forces in 1940-41 but vulnerable to the German 88mm gun.
The British Commonwealth army that fought in North Africa from 1941-1943, famous for its victory at El Alamein under Montgomery.
The RAF command that provided air support to the Eighth Army in North Africa, achieving air superiority by late 1942.
The Allied intelligence program that broke German Enigma codes. Ultra revealed Axis supply problems and allowed interception of convoys crossing the Mediterranean.
A vast salt marsh and sand sea south of El Alamein, impassable to vehicles. Its presence forced both armies to fight on the narrow coastal strip.
German fuel container design (Wehrmachtskanister) so superior to Allied designs that the British and Americans eventually copied it. The name comes from 'Jerry,' British slang for Germans.
